poem:
### Shortage

In a Texas town, morning unfolds,  
meds collected, a quiet concern.  
Outbreaks ripple, whispers of fear,  
as needles lie silent, shelves vacant.  
Through lingering doubt and sowed mistrust,  
we seek protection, tethered by choice,  
driven by stories of unseen battles,  
a reminder of fragility,  
and the power of a missing vial.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Texas cities run short of MMR vaccine as measles outbreak drives demand As measles cases continue to grow in Texas and New Mexico, with a second death, an unvaccinated adult, reported on Thursday, some Texas cities are seeing shortages amid soaring demand for the highly effective vaccine and as the top US health official, Robert F Kennedy Jr, sows disinformation and mistrust about vaccines. Ann and Paul Clancy were picking up medications at their local". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
